bib_record.title: Low-Flux Measurement of 235U Epicadmium Capture-to-Fission Ratio

free_txt: Preliminary data.
Experimental value 0.477 +- 0.022
Use of Mn and 252Cf as substitutes 0.492 +- 0.022
Effect of self shielding 0.500 +- 0.022
Deviation from 1/E spectrum 0.518 +- 0.023
Adjustment to 0.5-eV Cd cutoff 0.519 +- 0.023
1/E spectrum.
The experimental procedure requires the
measurement of 1) the relative reactivities rhoi of
samples of 235U, 252Cf, and manganese; 2) the
absolute capture rate for manganese RMn, and fission
rate for 235U, R25f; and 3) the spontaneous neutron
emission rate S for the 252Cf sample. The manganese
and 252Cf are used to establish the importance of
absorbed and fission neutrons, respectively. The only
additional information required is the number of
neutrons per 235U fission, nu25. When the results are
normalized to the same power level, the effective
capture-to-fission ratio:
alpha=(RMn/rhoMn)(rho25/R25f - (nu25*rhoCh/S))-1.
The equipment and
procedures reference.
The copper and aluminum samples and the empty can
used to derive the net 235U and manganese
reactivities were unaltered. The same 252Cf source
was used. The amounts of uranium and manganese-copper
alloy were increased approximately fourfold, to
compensate partially for the reduced signal caused by
the absence of thermalneutron effects. These new
samples were all 12.7 x 2.5 cm, with These new
samples were all 12.7 x 2.5 cm, with thicknesses of
0.005 cm for the uranium and 0.015 cm for the
manganese - copper. The oscillated uranium sample
weighed 2.7247 g and the four uranium samples used
for the absolute fission-rate determination were all
within 1.2% of this mass. The four manganese - copper
samples which were first oscillated and subsequently
irradiated ranged from 3.4 to 4.2 g.
The indicated standard errors reflect only
the reproducibility of the measurements and do not
allow for any additional uncertainty due to possible
systematic errors.
Table VI, page 253 of J,NSE,31,247,1968.
